Question: [Cybersecurity] QID:MC-001 Which term describes a hacker operating with malicious intent?
Options:
• A. White hat hacker
  • B. Gray hat hacker
  • C. Red hat hacker
  • D. Black hat hacker
OptionsWithCorrect:
• A. White hat hacker
  • B. Gray hat hacker
  • C. Red hat hacker
  • D. Black hat hacker
CorrectOptions:
D
Why correct: A black hat hacker operates with malicious intent, synonymous with an unauthorized hacker per the source text.
Why incorrect: A (white hat hacker) performs authorized security testing; B (gray hat hacker) operates without authorization but not maliciously; C (red hat hacker) conducts aggressive security testing, not necessarily with malicious intent.
Rationale: Tests recognition of the black hat hacker definition, using hacker-related color terms as distractors to challenge understanding and maintain consistency.
Metadata: Single-correct
Source: Section::2.1
Tags: Section::2.1 cybersecurity black-hat-hacker multiple-choice instance-1

Question: [Cybersecurity] QID:MC-003 Which are three types of threat actors most likely to have high levels of funding? (CHOOSE THREE)
Options:
• A. Nation-state
  • B. Unskilled attacker
  • C. Hacktivist
  • D. Organized crime
  • E. Insider threat
  • F. Shadow IT
  • G. APT
OptionsWithCorrect:
• A. Nation-state
  • B. Unskilled attacker
  • C. Hacktivist
  • D. Organized crime
  • E. Insider threat
  • F. Shadow IT
  • G. APT
CorrectOptions:
A, D, G
Why correct: Nation-state actors are supported by government resources, organized crime uses funding for commercial gain, and APTs have high sophistication requiring funding, per Section 2.1 and CompTIA SY0-701 objective 2.1.
Why incorrect: B (unskilled attacker) lacks resources; C (hacktivist) is ideologically driven; E (insider threat) is internal without external funding; F (shadow IT) is a practice, not an actor.
Rationale: Tests recall of funded threat actor types with plausible distractors from related concepts.
Metadata: Multiple-correct
Source: Section::2.1
Tags: Section::2.1 cybersecurity threat-actors funding multiple-choice instance-1 multiple-correct

Question: [Cybersecurity] QID:MC-004 Which are common threat vectors in cybersecurity? (CHOOSE THREE)
Options:
• A. Email
  • B. Encryption
  • C. Short Message Service (SMS)
  • D. Patching
  • E. Firewall
  • F. Auditing
  • G. Instant Messaging (IM)
OptionsWithCorrect:
• A. Email
  • B. Encryption
  • C. Short Message Service (SMS)
  • D. Patching
  • E. Firewall
  • F. Auditing
  • G. Instant Messaging (IM)
CorrectOptions:
A, C, G
Why correct: Email, SMS, and IM are message-based threat vectors used to deliver attacks like phishing, per Section 2.2 and CompTIA SY0-701 objective 2.2.
Why incorrect: B (encryption) secures data; D (patching) fixes vulnerabilities; E (firewall) blocks unauthorized access; F (auditing) tracks activities, none of which are threat vectors.
Rationale: Tests recall of message-based threat vectors with distractors from mitigation techniques to challenge differentiation.
Metadata: Multiple-correct
Source: Section::2.2
Tags: Section::2.2 cybersecurity threat-vectors multiple-choice instance-1 multiple-correct

Question: [Cybersecurity] QID:MC-005 Which are common attack surfaces in a supply chain? (CHOOSE THREE)
Options:
• A. Managed service providers (MSPs)
  • B. Firewalls
  • C. Encryption
  • D. Vendors
  • E. Patching
  • F. Auditing
  • G. Suppliers
OptionsWithCorrect:
• A. Managed service providers (MSPs)
  • B. Firewalls
  • C. Encryption
  • D. Vendors
  • E. Patching
  • F. Auditing
  • G. Suppliers
CorrectOptions:
A, D, G
Why correct: MSPs, vendors, and suppliers are inherent attack surfaces in a supply chain, as they involve external entities that can be exploited, per Section 2.2 and CompTIA SY0-701 objective 2.2.
Why incorrect: B (firewalls) blocks unauthorized access; C (encryption) secures data; E (patching) fixes vulnerabilities; F (auditing) tracks activities, none of which are supply chain attack surfaces.
Rationale: Tests recall of supply chain attack surfaces with distractors from mitigation techniques to challenge differentiation.
Metadata: Multiple-correct
Source: Section::2.2
Tags: Section::2.2 cybersecurity supply-chain attack-surfaces multiple-choice instance-1 multiple-correct

Question: [Cybersecurity] QID:MC-006 Which are types of vulnerabilities in a supply chain? (CHOOSE THREE)
Options:
• A. Service provider
  • B. Distributor
  • C. Hardware provider
  • D. Customer
  • E. Internal IT staff
  • F. Software provider
  • G. Third-party auditor
OptionsWithCorrect:
• A. Service provider
  • B. Distributor
  • C. Hardware provider
  • D. Customer
  • E. Internal IT staff
  • F. Software provider
  • G. Third-party auditor
CorrectOptions:
A, C, F
Why correct: Service provider, hardware provider, and software provider are external entities in a supply chain that can introduce vulnerabilities due to potential weaknesses, per Section 2.3 and CompTIA SY0-701 objective 2.3.
Why incorrect: B (distributor) handles logistics but is not listed as a vulnerability; D (customer) is the end recipient, not a vulnerability source; E (internal IT staff) is internal, not supply chain; G (third-party auditor) verifies compliance, not a vulnerability.
Rationale: Tests recall of supply chain vulnerability types with plausible supply chain-related distractors to challenge differentiation.
Metadata: Multiple-correct
Source: Section::2.3
Tags: Section::2.3 cybersecurity supply-chain vulnerabilities multiple-choice instance-1 multiple-correct

Question: [Cybersecurity] QID:MC-007a Which is a common motivation for nation-state threat actors?
Options:
• A. Philosophical beliefs
  • B. Financial gain
  • C. Disruption/chaos
  • D. Espionage
OptionsWithCorrect:
• A. Philosophical beliefs
  • B. Financial gain
  • C. Disruption/chaos
  • D. Espionage
CorrectOptions:
D
Why correct: Nation-state actors are commonly motivated by espionage to gather intelligence, per Section 2.1 and CompTIA SY0-701 objective 2.1.
Why incorrect: A (philosophical beliefs) motivates hacktivists; B (financial gain) motivates organized crime; C (disruption/chaos) motivates hacktivists or insiders, not typically nation-states.
Rationale: Tests recognition of nation-state motivations with distractors from other threat actors’ motivations to challenge differentiation.
Metadata: Single-correct
Source: Section::2.1
Tags: Section::2.1 cybersecurity nation-state motivations multiple-choice instance-1
